Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative: RUI: The natural history of mutations: sequence and fitness data from Arabidopsis thaliana mutation accumulation lines
Award.AbstractNarration:
Mutation is the source of genetic variation and organismal diversity, yet its precise contribution to evolution remains a fundamental problem in biology. This study combines next gen sequencing with classical mutation accumulation (MA) studies to describe sequence-level mutation rates. The researchers will employ whole genome sequencing to quantify the mutation rate and the spectrum of mutations in multiple genetic backgrounds of the plant Arabidopsis thaliana. Sequencing will be done on 100 MA lines derived from the Columbia accession of Arabidopsis thaliana, which have been assessed for performance in six natural field environments. Additional sequencing will include 40 lines from each of 8 additional sets of MA lines, established from naturally-collected founder genotypes from France and Sweden, and 50 lines from natural North American selections that have been identified to contain a unique haplotype grouping and divergence pattern of mutations similar to that found in classical MA lines. These data will estimate with much greater accuracy the type and rates of spontaneous mutation at the sequence level and will allow the research team to decompose the spectrum of mutations and connect them to field performance.

The synthesis of these datasets will enable the determination of which types of mutations are more likely to be beneficial, deleterious or neutral, and whether the effects of certain types of identified mutations are consistent across environments. There are societal, scientific and educational broader impacts to improving our understanding of mutations in plants. Mutation rates are important in plant breeding, in predicting evolution of herbicide resistance in weeds, and in predicting evolutionary responses of plants to major environmental changes such as climate change. Undergraduate students will have early access to sequence data and the opportunity to participate in the project. The researchers will develop a web-based educational module that allows students to learn 1) the causes and types of mutation 2) strategies for studying mutation 3) the importance of mutation to evolution and to human health and 4) how to use databases describing real mutations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The great irony of biology is that all of biological diversity, all that entails the adaptations that organisms have used to populate the diverse environments of earth, is a consequence of errors of replication, that is, mutations. Despite the elaborate mechanisms that ensure the fidelity of DNA replication, mutations still occur with effects ranging from simple changes in DNA sequence to whole genome replication. It is from these mutations that genetic variation is created de novo, and from which adaptations evolve through the action of natural selection acting on phenotypic variation with an underlying genetic basis.

Despite the role of mutation in the generation of biological diversity, the perspective has mostly been that mutations are deleterious, reflecting the notion that random changes in a complex organism are bound to have negative affects on that organism. Thus important questions include what proportion of mutations are deleterious or beneficial, are there certain types of mutations that are more likely to be beneficial, are there certain environments in which mutations are more likely be deleterious or beneficial, are there environments where mutations are more likely to have an effect on the phenotype? Furthermore, there are many more fundamental questions such as what is the mutation rate, is the mutation rate uniform across the genome, if not, then is the variation associated with polymorphisms within species or substitutions across species, and what are the molecular mechanisms for any such variation in mutation rate? These questions, have until recently, been difficult to address for two main reasons. First, mutations are a rare genomic event and how to detect a mutation, that needle in the haystack, is a technical challenge. Second, if one does have the ability to detect a rare new mutation, then it has been almost impossible to study the effects of that mutation in a realistic environment that determines whether a mutation is beneficial or not.

 

Through our National Science Foundation Funding we have been able to address some of the above questions, while those unanswered await further analyses from our research team. We have taken advantage of rapidly progressing sequencing technology to accurately detect new mutations through whole genomic sequencing. We sequence genomes before and after mutation events and where the sequence differs, and after validating, we designate a new mutation. We have conducted this work with the model plant organism mouse ear cress, Arabidopsis thaliana, that is small and does not move, allowing us to conducted highly replicated experiments in field environments. Also, its relative small genome size facilitates the detection of those rare mutation events that do occur. To study mutation effects in nature we first collected individuals from the extreme range of environments within its native European habitat, southern France and central Sweden. We then created genomic resources for studying mutations, including the well-known studied Columbia genotype. Then we planted individuals with and without mutations into the field environments that approximated the natural environments that mutations naturally occur within, knowing the mutations that these individuals had through whole genome sequencing.

 

To date, our most important findings are that we have been able to make robust estimates of mutation rates across the genome because of the high replication of our studies (>400 genomes completely sequenced). We found that every new A. thaliana offspring carries 1-2 new mutations, and these mutations are more likely to occur in transposable elements and centromeric regions. Deletion mutations are more likely to occur than insertions, consistent with the evolution of reduced genome size in the lineage leading to A. thaliana. The most exciting finding is that sites in the genome where we detected mutations are more likely to show genetic variation in nature, demonstrating a clear link between mutation and genetic variatio. Furthermore, we found that mutations are more likely to contribute to genetic variation in environments where the individual is stressed, suggesting that mutations can better contribute to breeding programs for adaptation to drought stress, salt tolerance, etc., and mutations can often be beneficial.

 

Our funding also contributed to the training of two postdocs who have moved on, one to a faculty position and the other to another postdoc focused on climate change biology. Two other US senior personnel also benefited from the funding contributing to their tenure and promotion. Nine different undergraduates contributed to the lab and fieldwork, receiving invaluable experience on how to work as a team to accomplish research objectives. Furthermore, the RUI collaboration has trained hundreds of undergraduates through the Undergraduate Phenotyping of Arabidopsis Knockouts) project centered at the College of Charleston: aiming to joins the curiosity and enthusiasm of undergraduate students for gaining hands on research experience with a novel experimental design approach for assaying phenotypes for this ecological genomic model system, and bring these data to the Arabidopsis community.
